description.narrative: Protected area conservation of eastern chimpanzees, western equatoria, South Sudan

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Protected area conservation of eastern chimpanzees, western equatoria, South Sudan

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to establish and sustain an effective conservation management and antipoaching presence by the Ministry of Wildlife Conservation and Tourism (MWCT) in the Game Reserves of Western Equatoria State, South Sudan for the purpose of protecting eastern chimpanzees. The recipient will develop an anti-poaching presence in the Game Reserves through the development of a basic network of access roads for deployment of rangers and general management and oversight of rangers; lay the foundation for future survey and monitoring efforts for eastern chimpanzees in the Game Reserves and neighbouring areas; work with the South Sudanese Ministry for Wildlife, Conservation, and Tourism (MWCT) to clarify and codify the legal boundaries of the Game Reserves and to identify other adjoining areas deserving protection; and establish the basis for long term conservation management and anti-poaching of the Game Reserves.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Assessment of Chimpanzees and Other Large Mammals in South Sudan Forests and..Implementation of Rapid Action Anti-trafficking Measures

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to improve the protection of chimpanzees and other large mammals in the remaining forest blocks of South Sudan. Specific activities include: (1) assessing the distribution and relative abundance of chimpanzees and other large mammals; (2) building local capacity to implement fieldwork and develop conservation strategies; (3) developing specific conservation strategies for chimpanzee protection and implementing rapid action activities; and (4) integrating the resulting data and recommendations into conservation and land-use planning processes.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Using innovative ivory anti-trafficking methods to protect elephants of South Sudan

description.narrative: To reduce ivory trafficking throughout South Sudan, the grantee will deploy a sniffer dog team to detect ivory, firearms and other wildlife products at key exit points and will establish a national ivory management system for seized ivory. Specific activities will include purchase and training of two sniffer dogs from an experienced company, building two dog kennels, training three local handlers from the government wildlife authority and ongoing operating costs of the dog team to conduct searches and seizures at Jube airport and Nimule border crossing, and the construction of a secure facility to store seized ivory, and to engage independent auditors to inventory existing ivory stock, train officers, and develop confiscation and storage procedures.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Contributed Funds

title.narrative: Strengthening protection and protected area management for the key elephant population in Southern National Park, South Sudan

description.narrative: This grant will support park protection and management in and around Southern National Park, South Sudan. Activities will include instituting a workable management plan with annual and quarterly reporting; training senior park staff in protected area management and rangers in law enforcement monitoring; providing support for elephant monitoring field operations including by disbursing patrol supplies, fuel and rations; identifying and tracking any transboundary movements with Garamba National Park, DRC; maintaining park infrastructure including vehicles and radios; and building local support for elephant protection through awareness campaigns and stakeholder meetings.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Strengthening protection and protected area management for the key elephant population in Southern National Park, South Sudan

description.narrative: This grant will support park protection and management in and around Southern National Park, South Sudan. Activities will include instituting a workable management plan with annual and quarterly reporting; training senior park staff in protected area management and rangers in law enforcement monitoring; providing support for elephant monitoring field operations including by disbursing patrol supplies, fuel and rations; identifying and tracking any transboundary movements with Garamba National Park, DRC; maintaining park infrastructure including vehicles and radios; and building local support for elephant protection through awareness campaigns and stakeholder meetings.

title.narrative: Using innovative ivory anti-trafficking methods to protect elephants of South Sudan: Phase 2

description.narrative: This project began with USFWS support in 2015 through the establishment of a national ivory stockpile management system in South Sudan. Prior to 2015, ivory was not collected or secured in a systematic way and therefore was vulnerable to theft and smuggling out of South Sudan onto the black market. In addition, USFWS supported the establishment of a canine anti-trafficking dog unit operating in Juba at the airport and road checkpoints and anti-trafficking sensitization activities targeting the public, foreigners, and government officials including law enforcement departments. This proposal will support activities for a two-year period, including operational support for the canine unit and securing confiscated or otherwise recovered ivory in the National Ivory Store (Objective 2), through 1) carrying out an ivory trafficking and canine unit use awareness program for national agencies acting at checkpoints and airports; 2) conducting ivory, firearms and other wildlife products detection activities at Nimule border crossing and locations in Juba; 3) conducting annual refresher training for the K9 team; 4) provision of continued technical support to the Ministry of Wildlife Conservation and Tourism in the management of the ivory in the National Ivory Store; and 5) conducting an annual public ivory stock management event.

title.narrative: PROTECTED AREA CONSERVATION & SURVEY OF EASTERN CHIMPANZEES, SW SOUTH SUDAN

description.narrative: to protect and survey eastern chimpanzees in the Game Reserves and surrounding areas of Gbudue (foremely Western Equatoria) State in southwestern South Sudan.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: PROTECTED AREA CONSERVATION AND SURVEY OF EASTERN CHIMPANZEES, SOUTH SUDAN

description.narrative: The overall goals of the project is to work with the Ministry of Wildlife Conservation and Tourism (MWCT) in the Game Reserves of Gbudue State, South Sudan to continue to develop anti-poaching presence and to work towards clarification, codification and eventual demarcation of the Game Reserve borders and adjacent "community forests" for the purpose of protecting eastern chimpanzees.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Protected area conservation and survey of eastern chimpanzees, South Sudan

description.narrative: The purpose of this 2-year project is to protect eastern chimpanzees by working with the Ministry of Wildlife Conservation and Tourism (MWCT) in two game reserves of Gbudue State, South Sudan to establish baseline chimpanzee abundance and lay the groundwork for sustained monitoring. Specific activities include: 1) continuing development of anti-poaching presence in the reserves; 2) continuing to clarify, codify and demarcate the legal boundaries of the reserves and to identify adjoining areas deserving of protection; and 3) further documenting chimpanzee abundance through camera trap surveys.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
